results.title: Sunday in Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Paul Olson, Gil Brealey, State Film Centre of Victoria and Melbourne Repertory Film Unit
results.brief_description: An experiment in the creative use of colour visuals, natural sound and dialogue commentary, this film shows the loneliness of the aimless wanderers in the city streets contrasted with those who have companionship on their Sunday. (Award: Special Award for an Experimental Film in the Australian Film Awards, Melbourne Film Festival, 1958) Rights held by Gil Brealey.

results.title: Spotlight on Australian Ballet
results.creator_credit: Doc K Sternberg, Geoff Powell, Loch Townsend, A Anderson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A survey of the development of ballet in Australia. The contribution made by such enthusiasts as Edouard Borovansky, Helene Kirsova, Laurel Martyn, Dorothy Stevenson, and other Australian dancers in training and encouraging aspiring dancers, and the untiring efforts of the various corps des ballets, the majority of whom have had to fit in their clases and training, and in many cases, their actual performances, after normal working hours, are presented as the background to the status of ballet in Australia in 1948. Narrated by John Bushelle.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Doc K Sternberg, Geoff Powell, Loch Townsend, A Anderson and Australian National Film Board

results.title: The Splendour and the Peaks
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Eric Thompson, Tasmanian Government Film Unit, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The Freycinet and Mount Field National Parks in Tasmania. Family parties and bushwalkers visit the Freycinet Peninsular where the red granite peaks of the Hazards dominate the sheltered waters of Coles Bay. From the summit of the highest peak, Mt Amos, there is a magnificent view of Wineglass Bay. At Mt Field we find the Russell Falls, Lake Dobson, Lake Seal, the towering dolerite columns of the watcher, and beautiful trees, birds and mosses to delight the visitor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Rogers, Eric Thompson, Tasmanian Government Film Unit, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Smokes and Lollies
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Penny Chapman, South Australian Film Corporation and 1:1 Films
results.brief_description: First film in a longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, aged thirteen and fourteen. They talk about their attitudes to sex and boys, pregnancy, abortion, marriage, school, parenthood and their careers. Their hopes and ambitions pose special questions for adults and young people alike. Edited by David Pulbrook; sound by Rod Pascoe and photographed by Tom Cowan.

results.title: Shine, Sir!
results.creator_credit: Kiwi Polish Company and The London Press Exchange
results.brief_description: An early advertising film, using animation, which promotes Australian made Kiwi boot and shoe polish and a fair capitalist system that allows for the initiative of youngsters. The ‘Imperial Hotel’ is left short staffed during World War I. Two young boys apply for the position of boot boys, but lament that they can’t clean boots. An Australian soldier, overhearing their conversation, offers each of them a tin of Kiwi boot polish which has impressive results and secures employment for them at the hotel.

results.title: School in the mailbox
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: By plane, train, buggy, bike, camel and car, school reaches the children of the Australian outback. Correspondence schooling is available for outback children from primary to high school standard, and for many Australians, the school lessons the mailman brings are the only ones they ever receive. Directed by Stanley Hawes, this documentary was produced in a remarkably short time and was sent to Paris as Australia’s contribution to the 1946 UNESCO conference. It was also nominated for an Academy Award for the best documentary short of 1947. Photographed by William Trerise, music by John Antill.

results.title: Robert Klippel. 3. Junk Sculpture, 1963
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description: Incorporating music and light, this film explores a sculpture by artist Robert Klippel. Made of machinery and sheet metal, the various plays on angle and light take the viewer inside the artwork and allow a range of perspectives.

results.title: The Queen in Australia
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The Queen in Australia is a landmark in Australian history. It not only records the first visit by a reigning monarch to Australia, it was also the first colour, feature-length documentary made in this country. This historic program provides nationwide coverage of the 1954 Royal Tour by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and HRH the Duke of Edinburgh - a two-month journey that took in every facet of Australian life: garden parties at Government House, dancers at the Tivoli, racing at Randwick, tennis at Kooyong with Rosewall and Hoad, cricket with the Don, even a meeting with Papua New Guinean tribal chiefs. The young royals visited every state in the nation, and the result is a remarkable and revealing insight into our nation in the 1950s.
